title: Landmark
text:
A landmark is a recognizable natural or artificial feature used for <a href="navigation">navigation</a>, a feature that stands out from its near environment and is often visible from long distances.
In modern use, the term can also be applied to smaller structures or features, that have become local or <a href="national%20symbol">national symbol</a>s.
Etymology.
In old English the word "landmearc" (from "land" + "mearc" (mark)) was used to describe an "object set up to mark the boundaries of a kingdom, estate, etc.". Starting from approx. 1560, this understanding of landmark was replaced by a more general one. A landmark became a "conspicuous object in a landscape".
A "landmark" literally meant a <a href="geographic%20feature">geographic feature</a> used by <a href="exploration">explorers</a> and others to find their way back or through an area. For example, the <a href="Table%20Mountain">Table Mountain</a> near <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a>, <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> is used as the landmark to help sailors to navigate around southern tip of <a href="Africa">Africa</a> during the <a href="Age%20of%20Exploration">Age of Exploration</a>. Artificial structures are also sometimes built to assist sailors in naval navigation. The <a href="Lighthouse%20of%20Alexandria">Lighthouse of Alexandria</a> and <a href="Colossus%20of%20Rhodes">Colossus of Rhodes</a> are ancient structures built to lead ships to the port.
In modern usage, a landmark includes anything that is easily recognizable, such as a <a href="monument">monument</a>, <a href="building">building</a>, or other <a href="structure">structure</a>. In <a href="American%20English">American English</a> it is the main term used to designate places that might be of interest to <a href="tourist">tourist</a>s due to notable physical features or historical significance. Landmarks in the <a href="British%20English">British English</a> sense are often used for casual <a href="navigation">navigation</a>, such as giving directions. This is done in American English as well.
In <a href="urban%20studies">urban studies</a> as well as in <a href="geography">geography</a>, a landmark is furthermore defined as an external point of reference that helps orienting in a familiar or unfamiliar environment. Landmarks are often used in verbal route instructions and as such an object of study by <a href="linguist">linguist</a>s as well as in other no fields of study.
Types.
Landmarks are usually classified as either natural landmarks or man-made landmarks, both are originally used to support navigation on finding directions. A variant is a "<a href="seamark">seamark</a>" or "<a href="daymark">daymark</a>", a structure usually built intentionally to aid sailors navigating featureless coasts.
Natural.
Natural landmarks can be characteristic features, such as <a href="mountain">mountain</a>s or <a href="plateau">plateau</a>s. Examples of natural landmarks are Table Mountain in South Africa, <a href="Mount%20Ararat">Mount Ararat</a> in Turkey, <a href="Uluru">Uluru</a> in Australia, <a href="Mount%20Fuji">Mount Fuji</a> in Japan and <a href="Grand%20Canyon">Grand Canyon</a> in the United States. Trees might also serve as local landmarks, such as jubilee oaks or <a href="conifer">conifer</a>s. Some landmark trees may be nicknamed, examples being "Queen's Oak", "Hanging Oak" or "Centennial Tree".
Human made.
In modern sense, landmarks are usually referred to as <a href="monument">monument</a>s or prominent distinctive buildings, used as the symbol of a certain area, city, or <a href="National%20symbol">nation</a>. Some examples include the "<a href="Statue%20of%20Unity">Statue of Unity</a>" in <a href="Narmada%20District">Narmada</a>, the <a href="White%20House">White House</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, the <a href="Statue%20of%20Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, the <a href="Eiffel%20Tower">Eiffel Tower</a> in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, the <a href="Colosseum">Colosseum</a> in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, <a href="Big%20Ben">Big Ben</a> in <a href="London">London</a>, the <a href="Ts%C5%ABtenkaku">Tsūtenkaku</a> in <a href="Osaka%20">Osaka </a>, "<a href="Christ%20the%20Redeemer%20%28statue%29">Christ the Redeemer</a>" in <a href="Rio%20de%20Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="Bratislava%20Castle">Bratislava Castle</a> in <a href="Bratislava">Bratislava</a>, the <a href="Space%20Needle">Space Needle</a> in <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a>, the <a href="Sydney%20Harbour%20Bridge">Sydney Harbour Bridge</a> or the <a href="Sydney%20Opera%20House">Sydney Opera House</a> (both in <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>), the <a href="Brandenburg%20Gate">Brandenburg Gate</a> in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, the <a href="Ch%C3%A2teau%20Frontenac">Château Frontenac</a> in <a href="Quebec%20%28city%29">Quebec (city)</a>, <a href="Place%20Stanislas">Place Stanislas</a> in <a href="Nancy%2C%20France">Nancy</a>, the <a href="CN%20Tower">CN Tower</a> in <a href="Toronto">Toronto</a>, or <a href="Palace%20of%20Culture%20and%20Science">Palace of Culture and Science</a> in <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>. <a href="Church%20%28building%29">Church</a> <a href="spire">spire</a>s and <a href="mosque">mosque</a>'s <a href="minaret">minaret</a>s are often very tall and visible from many miles around, thus often serve as built landmarks. Also <a href="town%20hall">town hall</a> towers and <a href="Belfry%20%28architecture%29">belfries</a> often have a landmark character.
